print_settings.Notes:: Print along the seam in the face.

description.text:
Described as the Universe's most compassionate murderous psychopaths the touch of a Weeping Angel is capable of sending its target back in time, allowing the Angel to feed off the remaining energy of a life not lived.

-=Design=-
This mask is based off of one I picked up off of Ebay. The original mask was majorly damaged and really to flimsy for anything given its condition. After scanning the mask I cleaned up the resulting mesh in Blender, erasing the damage, fixing details and making a few additions and corrections.

The mask is cut in half to make printing easier, and to fit the beds of most standard printers. It is sized to fit the normal human face, but obviously if printing for children print smaller.

-=Printing=-

As with most masks I intend to vacuform I printed this at 1.2mm wall thickness and 20% infill. If you're not planning on doing that thinner walls and less infill will work just fine.
When printing align so that the cut in the middle of the face is along the bottom of the bed for the best results.

-=Finishing=-
I printed my copy in ABS, and used super glue and bondo to put both halves together. I than vacuformed the final mask using a sheet of HIPS, and painted it using basic acrylic paint. I then used see through black cloth to fill in the eyes giving a more menacing visage.

-=Enjoy=-

author: FinePrint3D

description.text: WormStruder, as the name suggests is a worm drive based extruder. Takes design queues from Gregs and its derivatives, and utilises syvwlch Worm library for openscad. Uses a modified idler attachment without a screw (at the base). The body of this Extruder is around 15mm shorter (without motor) and 5mm narrower then a standard Gregs Accessible, but can use most of the same parts.

Update: Changed layout significantly, added filament feed hole
Update: Added groovemount for jhead, added derivation info
Update: Added arcol mount option
Update: Changed idler screw holes to M3's
Update: Added 1mm radius to base of worm gear cause grub screw was causing it to crack (on my print)
Update: changed the layout of the idler tension screw holder in the body (screw holes were a bit too tight and the sub for the bolt went back to far). Added a quick release to the top of the idler screw mechanism.
Update: forgot to rotate extruder bodies before upload
Update: modified extruder body, fillament feeder hole moved, filament hole widened at top, new idler mount holes. New idler design. Version 2
So i've completed a rather annoying redesign in freecad so i can change the base layout quickly. I have printed this and it does work however, i've not used it to print any objects yet so be prepared for it to fall apart, chew your printer to pieces and eat your household pet! It is most definitely a work in progress and treat it as such. The gearing ratio on this machine is variable depending on the gear you use (you can also create your own gear set from the code - this is quite simple, see below), but with the standard gears will vary between 1:15 - 1:18 (the standard Greg's accessible is around 1:4 or 1:5 from memory), so prepare for a really heavily geared down extruder (is it a good or bad thing? wont know until i do some prints). Its a little noisier then normal geared extruders. Currently designed around the jhead hotend (as in the top that extends into the extruder), im not sure what other hotends have similar dimensions but if yours doesnt fit or you know the differences in way i can easily understand, im happy to design a fitting for it. All STL's are repaired prior to being uploaded. How to build this: You will need the following "bits"
2 of M3x50 - Idler tensioner bolts
2 of M3 Springs of appropriate size (or rubber grommets).
2 of M4x?? - for mounting on your carriage/hotend (if you have a gregs extruder currently, the same bolts should surfice)
2 of M3x10 - stepper motor mounting screws (replace with whatever suits you really).
3 of 608z (or similar) 8mm bearings.
1 of idler bearing mount bolt as used on most Greg's and derivatives (optional)
2 of M3x30 - for groovemount option You will need to print the following:
Worm Extruder.stl
Worm Extruder - Tensioner.stl
wormonly.stl (SEE NOTE ABOUT WORM GEAR) and one of the gearonly stl's (15, 16, 17 or 18 teeth, for a 1:15-1:18 gearing ration), i suggest the 16 or 17 for now (or print them all and see which one you like!). Put the thing together in the same way you would put together a Gregs accessible extruder, leaving the stepper motor till last. Stepper motor only uses 2 mount holes (for now). NOTE ABOUT THE WORM
The worm has a big circle at the bottom, this is there simply for printing purposes and can be removed post-print (it may not actually be required). The worm should also print just fine with no support (though, make sure your using a reasonably newish version of slic3r - one that prints perimeters from the inside outward). Optional bits
You can print the Worm Extruder - Idler Bolt.stl if you wish (its just a simple plastic replacement for the metal bit thats in most extruders, i found it worked ok)
You can also print the "Worm Extruder....Spacer....stl" file, you might find this works better for you if you have a Gregs or Wades hobbed bolt as its sized to move the hobbing to the right location in this extruder. Creating your own gears - pull down my git repo (see below), go into the directory, FromOpenScad/syvwlch-worm and edit the makefile, at the top of the makefile there is two lines:
CUSTOM_TEETH=16
CUSTOM_RADIUS=14
Changing these will change the worm/toothed gear and next you type "make", this should produce two stls in the "stls" directory called "wormonly-TEETH-RADIUS.stl" and "gearonly-TEETH-RADIUS.stl" where TEETH and RADIUS are the values you put in the makefile (these are the two most important values for changing the gears. You can edit other values by opening up worm-gears.scad and modifying the variables at the top of the file. Todo's

  • Originally, all the steppers I use are Rattm's but recently i stumbled onto a smaller motor called a vexta c4041-9012 (seen on this page http://www.duke.edu/web/isis/gessler/topics/steppers.htm). You can see the motor in one of the pics I've attached, its got about half the size and torque of a rattm. I bought it simply to see if it will drive this extruder so one of my first todos is to attach that motor (when i can get the gear off it which is proving a tedious task)

  • Figure out how to get 3 motor mount holes going.

  • Add design work for alternative hotends.
    • Background
    I originally decided I wanted to do this for no good reason i can remember and spent quite some time with the brilliant openscad libraries generating STL's, importing them into freecad so I could come up with a (rather complex and large) design for a worm gear that could print and attach to a stepper - this was all in vane as the worm prints quite well without modification or support and standing up.
    Once i'd completed it, I decided I might as well print the rest of the parts, hook it up and see what happens. I expected it to rip itself to pieces in several ways - I printed the body with zero infill and the gears/idler with 50% infill. I half expected the lack of any substance to the extruder body would tear the idler mount straight off when i tightened the idler, i also expected the worm would tear the teeth off the toothed gear and/or the worm would break off the shaft of the stepper. None of these things happened, in fact it extruded very well on my 0.35mm jhead hotend. You can also see in some of the pics where i've not changed the brim settings after printing the worm (5mm brim) and so the gears have lots of little thin chunks of brim hanging off them from where the worm gear shredded them (nice way of removing brim from a print!). The original files for this GPL'd object exist under https://github.com/takigama/pjrun/tree/master/WormScrewExtruder and https://github.com/takigama/pjrun/tree/master/FromOpenScad/syvwlch-worm The body and idler are done entirely in freecad, the worm and gears are done entirely in openscad. The openscad components are dependent on syvwlch's worm library (https://github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8821), the general layout of the body takes queues from many of the Greg's Accessible+derivatives extruders (See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8252).

description.text:
This is for the FT mini Guinea pig, I couldn't find anything that could protect the underside of the plane so I quickly designed this. I printed this with 4 top and bottom layers @10% infill red PLA. A simple set up with supports at the front when printing.

I have installed this with standard bbq skewers and on the inside of the plane I have used plastic straws held in with hot melt glue to guide the skewers through to the other side,I also found this adds and extra catch for the front nose ( not that it needs it). The front can still be removed by taking the newly installed landing sled and your standard nose skewer out.

If you find the front doesn't quite touch the nose of the plane then just heat it up a little and bend it up to help reduce drag.

print_settings.Notes:: At least 50% infill is required for speeds higher than 7000 RPM, or else the structure may collapse while centrifuging (happened to one prototype).  Also printed out of hardened PLA, although standard PLA prototypes held up just as well.  ABS and nGen collapsed under load past 5000 RPM at 30% infill.

description.text:
My lab has been in need of a compact centrifuge for 1.7 mL Eppendorf tubes.

From the work by KemFic on a DIY Arudino powered centrifuge from old hard drive spindles, I modified the design for a more secure structure and fit on a standard 3.5" hard drive (molded to the spindle shape and screw-hole locations). The resulting structure is more stable at higher RPMs.

The code has also been modified (https://github.com/ekurt1/Hard-Drive-Centrifuge), with automated and manual speed calibration options, with work being done on RPM vs G-force readings and an emergency shutdown mode. The code has also been modified for our purpose in using a server hard drive, with speeds of up to 15,000 RPM.

The remaining tasks for the build are a secure, weighted enclosure (since vibrates heavily during use).

description.text:
The SQ12 records surprisingly well video for as small and cheaply priced as it is. I wanted to run this on my quad, but the original 40 degrees was too low for faster flying. I modified it by changing the degrees to 50 and removed the tunnel-thing (whatever it is called) on the back. The thinner back part should help to reduce vibrations to the camera itself by being thinner. This easily mounts to a top plate with a ziptie or can be threaded through with a battery strap.

I laid this over on its side so that it should print real easy as it is. I've been printing it with supports and they are easy to remove since they are just in the camera and button openings. I printed it with TPU at 80% infill and 0.2mm layer thickness. It is snug fit and the camera lens extrudes just enough to help hold it in the mount. Kudos to the original designer.

author: SaltyDubs

title: How to run Customizer on your own computer

description.text:
This is a useless customizable thing, to demonstrate how to create a customized STL on your own computer instead of having to rely on Thingiverse's on-line Customizer app, which has a history of breaking at random moments, sometimes for extended periods. At the moment when I'm creating this, attempting to run Customizer on the website will result in this error, which occurs at the side of the Thingiverse server:
“/usr/local/bin/openscad/openscad: error while loading shared libraries: libCGAL.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory”

Another advantage of running Customizer locally even if the on-line one works fine, is that you do not need to wait for your turn in the processing queue. Moreover, you have a much better and faster preview of the model, which you can rotate and zoom freely.

In a nutshell, the steps to run Customizer on your own computer, are (see images for steps 3 to 8):

  1. Download and install OpenSCAD, preferably the latest development snapshot.
  2. Download the .scad file of the Thing you want to customize, and open this file in OpenSCAD.
  3. Go to the Preferences menu, and in the ‘Features’ section, ensure Customizer is enabled (you only need to do this once).
  4. Uncheck ‘Hide Customizer’ in the View menu to show the Customizer UI at the right. (If you are using an older OpenSCAD version, this item won't be there, and your only option is to edit the values in the source on the left.)
  5. Create a new preset, and edit the values as you would in the online Customizer.
  6. Hit the Preview button (F5) to get a quick preview.
  7. When ready, hit the Render button (F6). This may take a while.
  8. When the model has been rendered, click the STL button to export the custom STL file.

A bit of extra info:
Customizer is based on OpenSCAD, a program that can generate 3D models out of a set of instructions. A customizer file is just a .scad file with specific formatting. You can use any version of OpenSCAD to load and edit a customizer file, but I highly recommend using the latest development snapshot, because it contains the same kind of interface as the Customizer app on the Thingiverse website. You can create multiple presets (these will be stored in a JSON file next to the .scad file).

OpenSCAD has two modes: a fast preview mode, and a (usually slow) render mode which produces a model that can be saved for printing. Tweak the customizer parameters in preview mode, and only render when satisfied with the preview, because rendering can take long depending on how complex the model is. Finally, you must export the model to an STL file which you can then print like any other file you would have downloaded.

title: Animorphic Camera Lenses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My friend has a fancy camera, and wanted to try out an animorphic lens filter. Before he dropped the cash on the expensive ones (like this: https://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/1338799-REG/vid_atlantic_vamp77cbkh_77mm_cinemorph_filter_kit.html) we tested by printing some basic ones that he attaches with adhesive strips.

Since he had different size lenses, I made 3 sizes: 47mm, 67mm, and 77mm. All of them are 2mm thick to make quick prints that will fit to the camera lens easily.

If you need a custom size, I've included the STEP or F3D files for the 47mm one. I then just scaled the object non-uniformly on the X and Y axis to make other sizes, leaving the thickness at 2mm. Feel free to make your own if your lenses are different sizes.

title: Control Panel for Automatic Garden Waterer

description.text:
I'm sharing this file more for inspiration than to download and print out this file. It was custom-made for a project that I've been working on that switches a valve to water plants in the garden. It has a manual switch to control the valve or an Atmel Atmega328 AVR set up as an Arduino that is used as a timer attached to a relay to display information via a 16x2 character LCD and automatically turn the valve off after a adjustable amount of time. You can read more about it on my blog at:
http://tinkeringetc.blogspot.com/2012/08/automatic-garden-waterer-part-2.html SketchUp file is included.

I don't expect anybody to actually print this out, but feel free to comment or message me if you have any questions.
For some reason it won't print directly from a .stl export in SketchUp. I have to repair it with netfabb Studio first.

description.text:
Replacement Wear Ring for the Polaris 180/280/360/380/360 BlackMax/380 BlackMax Pool Cleaners / Sweeps.

I've settled on using TPU plastic since it is flexible enough to allow the ring to be opened and installed. All other plastic types I've tried are too stiff. There might be another flexible filament that is slightly stiffer than TPU that might work fine as well, but none of the various PLA, PETG or ABS that I've tried is flexible enough.

I am conducting a test to see how these hold up... in the photo from left to right: an original quite-worn wear ring, 100% infill white TPU, 50% infill red TPU and finally 50% infill white TPU.

title: Anova sous vide circulator to coolerbox adapter

description.text:
A support for Anova Culinary's immersion circulator to mount it to a Curver 10 liter cooler box. May fit other storage- or cooler boxes.

There are two versions. One can be used as a separate support to adjust the height of Anova relative to the water surface. It may be glued to the box cover if wanted.
The second version consists of 3 parts. One goes below the cover, one in the middle and one on top of the cover, and it can be attached using bolts and nuts.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed using black Ultimaker PLA.

For the first version, I drilled a 62mm hole to the cover of the cooler box. Anova shaft is 60mm, but the 62mm hole saw was the closest in size that I had. Then I glued the riser part on it with cyanoacrylate glue.

For the other version, I also drilled a 62mm hole (and four 5mm mounting holes) and bolted it on the cover of the cooler box.

So far have done three of these for family and friends who have Anova circulators and I haven't encountered any issues.

title: Barn Tape Holder and Small Supply Holder

description.text: This is a multi-purpose barn which is accompanied by other farm themed parts. It is intended to be a tape holder and a holder for other smaller supplies like paper clips and erasers. It is made out of four separate parts; the barn, the tape holder, the tape rod, and the barn roof. When the barn roof is placed on top the tape comes out of the window slot. In the pictures shown the tape holder piece does not fit correctly due to an error in measurement, but the file for it has the correct measurements for the tape holder and will fit properly into the slot for it on the barn.

Lesson Plan

These are the instructions to build the barn and roof.

Part 3: Barn walls
Extrude Boss
Sketch a 9.5 cm by 9.5 cm box
Extrude up to 5 cm
Cut Extrude
Sketch a rectangle .2 from every side except the front wall, which will be 5 cm apart
Cut extrude down by 4.7 cm
Boss Extrude
On the front side of the figure, sketch a rectangle that is 9 cm by 4.4 cm
Extrude by .2 cm
Boss extrude
Directly above that rectangle sketch another rectangle that is 9.5 by .3 cm
Extrude by .3 cm
Boss Extrude
Offset original sketch of rectangle by .4 cm
Extrude to .3 cm
Linear sketch pattern
Sketch a centerline down the middle of the offsetted rectangle
Retrace each side and offset by .3 cm
Sketch a vertical line .2 cm from the edge of the box on both sides
Linear sketch pattern the line on both sides with .2 cm spacing
Boss extrude
Sketch a pentagon shape with a horizontal line at the top up 5 cm
Extrude inwards by .2 cm
Boss extrude
On top of the front wall box sketch a rectangle that is 4.8 cm by 3 cm
Extrude by 4.8 cm
Offset
Offset sketch by .5 cm
Cut extrude
Cut extrude offsetted sketch by 2.25 cm
Cut extrude
Sketch a circles on either side of the inside walls of the rectangle that have a .5 cm radius
Cut extrude both circles by .2 cm
Cut extrude
Sketch a rectangle on both circles until top edge
Cut extrude by .2 cm

Part 4: Roof
Boss extrude
Sketch a pentagon that has a height of 5cm and is 10cm long that has a horizontal line as the top (6 sides)
Extrude out 10 cm
Shell feature
Hollow out the inside creating roof walls .2 thin
Cut extrude
On one wall, sketch a rectangle centered on the panel that is 4.5cm by 4.5 cm
Cut extrude through all
Linear sketch pattern
Sketch 5 perpendicular horizontal lines across the panel sides 1 cm in from the side, sketch a vertical lines connecting the top of the panel to the next horizontal line (in between each set of horizontal lines)
Linear sketch pattern 9 more vertical lines each 1 cm apart

description.text:
28BYJ-48 Mechanical Actuator #4

I thought it would be cool to see what kind of Mechanical Actuators we could make using the 28BYJ-48 stepper motor and mostly 3D printed parts. The 28BYJ-48 is the motor that comes with most Arduino kits. It's a 5v dc motor with a max rpm of 15 and is capable of around 4 oz force/in of torque. You can get these motors with the driver for around $2 each.

Linear Ball Bearing Stepper Slide

This is a linear bearing slide driven by a 28BYJ-48 stepper motor. The linear bearing utilizes standard .177 (4.5mm) caliber steel BB’s and has adjustment screws for setting the preload. The trapezoidal drive screw utilizes an integral ball bearing also made with BB’s to handle the thrust loads of the slide.

I included two different lead screws; a twin lead screw with a 1/2” pitch and a quadruple lead screw with a 1” pitch. Given the max rpm of the stepper motor is 15 rpm the twin lead screw will result in the carriage traveling at 7-1/2 in per/min and the quadruple lead screw will travel at 15 in per/min.

The linear bearing actually works very well and the BB’s recirculate just as they are supposed to! There is some noise and vibration as the BB’s are not caged and I think they meet a little resistance as they recirculate back into the bearing. On the next version I’m going to split the housing like an actual linear bearing to see if it improves on the vibrations.

This slide will actually move over 25 lbs with the twin lead screw! If you have seen the previous Dovetail Stepper Slide it could move around 7lbs so this version has a 4x’s the load capacity do to its reduced friction. However the load is not as stable as it is on the dovetail slide. I believe the dovetail slide can handle more load it’s just the stepper motor is not strong enough to push it.

The mounting holes on the base, carriage, and the endplate all match up so multiple slide assemblies can be bolted together to make a two or three axis cartesian system.

=====================================================================

Required Components

  • M3 Nut (14x)
  • M3 SHCS x 10mm lg. (12x)
  • M3 SHCS x 20mm lg. (2x)
  • .177 BB’s (8x) for Thrust Bearing
  • .177 BB’s (8x) for Linear Bearing
  • 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor

Assembly

To assembly the linear bearing the first thing you need to do is install the two M3 x 20mm screws and nuts into the carriage for the preload adjustment. Don’t tighten the screws up at this point. Then install the carriage on the rail and set them both upside down. Fill each groove with 20 BB’s and install the caps. Once the bearing is packed with BB's adjust the screws to get the desired preload. If you have the linear bearing properly set you can build the thrust bearing flange.

Note: Using grease on the thrust bearing, drive screw, and nut is going to improve the load capacity and the lifecycle greatly as well as reduce noise and vibration. I would not put any lube on the ball bearings, it could cause issues with the balls recycling. If you are having trouble with the BB’s recycling you can also try taking out one of the BB’s on each side.

Update

3/12/18 - When I first uploaded the files I accidently put in a triple lead screw instead of a double. The new file; "BS-V1-SCREW-1_2-DBL.STL", has a double lead to match that on the carriage.

description.text:
This is a case for 3 LCD voltage meters which can be used to quickly test the per-cell voltage of lipo batteries via the balance lead, or any other batteries with a 2.54mm pin header or balance lead.

You will need:

  • 3x Mini Digital Volt Meters (Banggood, a couple of bucks each)
  • 4x 4 pin-headers
  • Some silicone wire
  • Hot Glue
  • Superglue/CA

This tester will tell you the per-cell voltage of up to 3s in about a second, which is great if you are checking lots of batteries.

I designed this to solve a problem I saw with some of the available single-LCD testers, which cycle through readings on a single LCD, and can take up to 5 seconds to tell the voltage of the whole battery and more to tell the voltage of the entire battery.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10% Rectilinear

Notes:

Nothing special about the print. Print with the face side down.

You might want supports for the header-pins slot if your printer struggles with bridging.

1. Test that the volt meters are calibrated correctly. They have an adjustment screw on the back.
  2. Print all the things, clean them up and make sure they all fit (the lid may require some adjusting with a file or knife)
  3. Measure wire, and wire up the pin headers
  4. Glue pin headers in place with CA. This keeps it in place and also helps make sure the pins can't move in the headers.
  5. Place voltmeters and solder in
  6. Test it to make sure it all works
  7. Glue the voltmeters in with hot glue
  8. Glue the back on with hot glue

title: Max's Hi-Fi Headphone  / Headset Holder (Wall & Under Desk Mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hello and thank you for taking a look at my design!

I wanted a holder for headphones, but even though there are some great designs here, I couldn't find one that I liked. I wanted something sturdy but not bulky, that would follow the curvature of standard HI-Fi headphones and most of all, I found no design that was ergonomic.
So I had a go at it!

I try to make my designs sturdy, stylish, economic, functional, and most important of all, easy to print!

There are 3 variants:

  • Standard under-desk mount
  • Low profile wall mount
  • Wall mount for heavier headphones

I've tried this even with my heaviest headset (Turtle Beach Stealth 800x) @ 360g and it did not deform. If you have a heavier headset I'd suggest printing in ABS instead.

Also, the back 'wall' is tall enough to support a 3M medium command strip.

I'd be happy to see your prints and suggestions / comments! I hope this helps!

If you are curious about the XBox Elite Wireless Controller mount shown in the pic, here you go!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2556069

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

No

No

0.1 - 0.2

15%

I printed this in PLA and tried 0.1, 0.15 and 0.2 layer height, with linear advance printing @ 7200mm/min. They all came out great!

I used standard drywall screws.

A case designed around the Duet Wifi, design choices were to focus on airflow while remaining svelte.

  • Two 50mmx10 fans directing air over and above board. Channels to direct air under stepper drivers.
  • Built in zip tie points along wall for cable management and two more in front to secure power and bed wires.
  • Full rear panel access without having to remove anything.
  • Reference notes recessed on inside wall for wire layout.

  • Screws are threaded for M4-7 (10mm long is what I'm using)

  • Two versions uploaded at the moment, one with feet and one without. I recommend supports for the bridge between the board and fans.

Thanks to the HEVO facebook group for being a great sounding board in laying this box out, much appreciated!

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 V2 Spool holder

description.text: Designed for use on the Wanhao Duplicator I3 V2 and in such a way that no supports are needed. Can be printed in one go on a 200x200 bed but recommend you print the bearing and clamp pins with 100% infill and the rest at 33%. Sliced with Simlify3d V4. You will need to print 4 clamp, 4 bearing pins, 2 lock-nuts and purchase 4 22mm x 8mm x 7mm bearings. I used PLA+ but please note, do NOT over tighten the pins, the shoulder may or may not site flush (depends on your printer settings. Hot end 192, bed 70 coated with a thin layer of glue stick, so no rafts or brims either. I is adjustable for different size spools 35mm to 75mm wide. The clamp legs could probably be edited to fit different printers.

remixed_from.title: CR-10 hanging fan/part cooler for stock, Microswiss and E3D v6 hotends

remixed_from.author: jneilliii
remixed_from.title: Radial Fan Fang for Creality CR-10

description.text:
I wanted to use this fang fan by jneilliii:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2237084

It connects quite well to this fan duct by superpotatofudge:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2160958

However, that fan duct blocks a lot of airflow out the sides of the heatsink. Since the x-carriage itself blocks airflow out the back of the heatsink on the CR-10, that combo would have hindered cooling quite a lot, I suspect.

Anyway, I much preferred this hanging bracket method by junaling:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2473423

But junaling's bracket doesn't really jive with jneilliii's fang - you end up with the fang blowing about 8mm too far toward the x-carriage, missing the molten plastic completely.

To solve the problem, I remixed junaling's "bracket_face_v10.stl" to adapt jneilliii's fan onto junaling's bracket.

To use:
1) Choose & print one of the 4x fan designs from jneilliii.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2237084
2) Print junaling's "bracket_end_v10.stl"
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2473423
Note: Due to PLA shrinkage, I had to print this at 102% scale to properly fit my Micro Swiss hotend.
3) Choose & print one of my adapters.

As for my adapters, I'm personally using the 12.5mm one, with cutout. I used the cutout because I was nervous about getting PLA too close to the heating block. The 12.5mm thickness still has the fangs just a hair too close to the x-carriage.

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Any of the "upright" versions should print with no support, but you might need to use a brim or raft to increase bed adhesion.
Any of the "flat" versions will need bed-only support, but shouldn't have any problem with adhesion.
This was designed to hold the two Medela breast pump bottles that we have. It keeps them from tipping over as we carry the bottles to/from the refrigerator.

description.text:
Voici ma première pièce réalisé avec FREECAD. Je joins le fichier 3D.

Il s'agit d'un moyeu central avec roulement pour une bobine de 55 mm.

English Below
Imprimez votre container geocaching à vos propres dimensions.
Si vous êtes un utilisateur de Openscad, vous pourrez créer un container geocaching à vos dimensions. Il vous suffira de choisir le diamètre du filetage de M6 à M54, la hauteur du container, le texte éventuel que vous voulez graver sur votre container et d’exécuter le fichier Container_geo_caching.scad.

Pour afficher le corps du container uniquement Positionnez les variables :
            Do_you_want_the_box="YES";
            Do_you_want_the_top="NO";

Pour afficher le couvercle du container uniquement Positionnez les variables :
            Do_you_want_the_box="NO";
            Do_you_want_the_top="YES";

Les 4 fichiers suivants doivent être présents sur le même répertoire :

  • Container_geo_caching.scad (principal)
  • dimension_filetage_iso.scad
  • helix_extrude.scad (thanks to gaellafond, Helix library for OpenSCAD thing:2200395)
  • VIS_ISO.scad

ENGLISH VERSION

Print your container with your own dimensions.
If you are an Openscad user, you will be able to create a geocaching container with your own size. You will just have to select the thread diameter (from M6 to M54), the container’s high, the possible text you want to engrave on the container, and execute the file: Container_geo_caching.scad.

To have only the main part of the container, please set the 2 variables:
            Do_you_want_the_box="YES";
            Do_you_want_the_top="NO";

To have the main part of the container, please set the 2 variables:
            Do_you_want_the_box="NO";
            Do_you_want_the_top="YES";

The 4 Following files must exist on the same directory:

  • Container_geo_caching.scad (principal)
  • dimension_filetage_iso.scad
  • helix_extrude.scad (thanks to gaellafond, Helix library for OpenSCAD thing:2200395)
  • VIS_ISO.scad

I was not very happy to find that the local store sold these for around $8.00 a piece, so I designed this with my son and made it a father/son bonding experience. He learned some Fusion360, and he learned how to fix the rails on our deck.

I suggest using the highest infill you can, this is to support a guard rail on your deck, or keep your existing rails from slipping around. One version is for a new install (with a back), the other was intended to be a repair to an existing rail (without a back).

title: Ocie's Box - Enclosure for Duet Wifi - V3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 9-Mar-2018: Back and Lid revised to V3. Neither part is compatible with V2 models, so V2 models removed for clarity. Changes for V3:

  • Replaced single center lid screw with 4 perimeter screws. This helps with lids that bow slightly upon removal from the printer due to internal residual stresses generated from differential cooling during print.
  • Enlarged wire hooks for better cable management
  • Added a slot to the side wall to allow PanelDue cable to exit into the vertical extrusion slot, if you want to mount your display on top of the printer
  • Enlarged cable bundle slot at the bottom of the enclosure for easy of wiring
  • Reduced lid thickness from 3mm to 2mm to decrease printing time (18% reduction for PETG, 10% reduction for PLA)
  • Removed all features related to mounting a secondary fan, as I believe a single fan will be sufficient for cooling.

For screenshots of all changes, see attached photos

Here is an enclosure for the Duet Wifi controller that is designed to fit 3030 extruded framing. STEP files are included, so you can easily modify the design to fit your application.

The key features are:

  • Active cooling under stepper drivers using a 40x20mm fan
  • Wire management hooks to keep cabling under control without having to jam the cables into tight slots
  • Space to fit auxiliary boards. M3 screw bosses provided for the following aux boards:
    • 5V 3A USB power jacks. you can fit two of these for a total of 4 USB powered devices (LED lights, Raspberry Pi, etc): http://amzn.to/2HUPW6H
    • MOSFET. you can use one of these in place of one of the USB power boards if you are powering a bed heater that draws more than the Duet's 18A circuit can provide: http://amzn.to/2ozFxFg
  • Lugs for two 5-pin Wago connectors (221-415) to be used as terminal blocks: http://amzn.to/2FazZra
  • Cable lugs have holes for 3mm nylon filament to be used for wire support (Prusa method) and are compatible with Jason Canning's excellent ball-joint cable covers:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2787748
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2735303
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2810713

Lid prints with no support
Back Prints with support needed only under the three external cable lugs

title: Garage Door Safety Sensor Sun-Shield
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My garage door runs N/S, so around 1pm the sun saturates the safety sensor and prevents the garage door from closing. I could have probably just swapped the transmitter/receiver, or perhaps used a toilet paper roll and some duct tape, but hey I have a 3D printer. This attaches to the mount with a couple small binder clips, and blocks the sun adequately. Tube is tilted 30deg, and the binder clip solution allows enough slack to adjust manually.

Model designed in tinkercad, let me know if you'd like it.

author: PhysiciSteve

title: Baby or Pet Gate Baseboard Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This baby or pet gate baseboard bracket is designed to enable the use of certain types of pressure mounted baby or pet gates against a baseboard with quarter round.

Installation requires two appropriately sized screws per bracket because the bracket can slide too easily if mounted by compression alone.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

25%

Simply put, I measured the dimensions of the quarter round and of the gate rounded pressure disc. I sketched the side profile of the part interfacing with the baseboard, extruded it long enough to prevent the bracket from pivoting in place, and then projected a canvass perpendicularly to sketch the hole for the rounded pressure disc. I wanted to keep the bracket within a certain size but also wanted it to be strong and stylish. These constraints influenced the design, resulting in six spokes. It took two version to get the right fit because the quarter round was not quite a quarter of a round.

author: JNJLabbe

title: Hockey Puck Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: fun like glasses by optimaker "like facebook"
I've made these in PLA, ABS, and TPU. ABS seems too brittle and you can easily damage when removing support material. TPU works best IMO. It gives it that extra grip.

This is the third attempt to rebuild the mechanism of Theo Jansens "strandbeests". Although the mechanism seems to work flawlessly I did not have time (this was a very short termed school project) to work out a proper construction plan for the joints consisting of screws, bolts, square as well as round metal tubes. Due to the shortage of time I unfortunately had to cancel this project and could only print out four of the six legs I intended to build.
Please note: this model is still work in progress and optimized to be built with m4 hex-head screws.

In the file "Composition Prototype III.pdf" you can see how the legs are put together. IMPORTANT:
To get a stable walk the mechanism requires at least 6 legs, of which always two are held together by the two different camshafts (0ÃÂ° and ÃÂ°120). So you need to print all parts - except the camshafts - twice in order to get one pair of legs.

As you can see on the left, there are a ton of features to this model. I started with the outside profile from the hinge pin hole. Extruded that sketch and used pads and pockets (sketch-based features) to get the general shape. Used some drafts and chamfers. I saved most of the blends for last. Saving the blends for last makes it easier to rollback and make changes to your model without it blowing up too much.

title: Magnetic Tetra-Bricks!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A magnetic version of the Tetra-Bricks.

The .stl file is set up for 3/8" diameter 1/16" thick neodymium magnets. You'll need to pause the print at two different times to insert the magnets. See ( https://3dprinterwiki.info/duplicatori3/pause-at-layer-height/ ) for help altering the g-code to automatically pause. For me, printing from the PC using Repetier-host was the easiest way to pause. Then you can just insert @pause in the g-code to pause.

To find the right places to pause, check your g-code preview in your slicer. Find the layer that first starts to cover over the bottom magnet space and then the top of the side magnet spaces. See the PauseInsert_x.jpg images for reference. For me this was at the start of 14 and then layer 76 but it may be different for your slicer.

Watch the polarity of the magnets for the best results you'll want two sides with N out and two sides with S out. Then the Tetras will always have 2 faces that will stick together. The easiest way to do this is at the second insert pause. There two of the new magnets will be attracted to the one on the bottom. The last new magnet will be slightly repelled and will stick up a bit. For me, the print head pushed this last magnet in place as it printed over it.

Note: Neodymium magnets will start to permanently lose their strength at 80 degrees C. Printing with PLA should not be an issue but you may want to limit the bet temperature to 75 C or less for other materials.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You'll need to pause the print twice to insert the magnets. Here is a link with instructions for various setups. https://3dprinterwiki.info/duplicatori3/pause-at-layer-height/

description.text:
This is an anti-rotation, flush mount adapter to make your antenna mod look stock. The process and required case modification can be a challenge if you don't have the right tools so proceed at your own risk! I used a dremel to cut out the required hole and 180 sand paper to make the top of the taranis flush. There is also a center marked template included for marking the required hole. It is on the small side to get you close, then slowly trim away until your case closes completely.

A more detailed (with more photos) build guide will be made and posted soon. Any questions until then I'll be happy to answer.

Had a tuxedo shirt, but as I'm uncultured swine I had no idea how to affix the top of the shirt I was using cheap carabiners for a while). After some googling, I realized tuxedo studs were a thing, but even the cheapest set on Amazon was like $30. Couldn't find a model on Thingiverse either, but found
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2328403/
and DuaneIndeed was gracious enough to take some measurements. After about five minutes in F360 and a couple minutes printing, I have a way to close my shirt! One of my studs broke upon trying to unbutton my shirt, but they were all strong enough to hold while wearing them even at super-low quality (and they cost about a penny, so NBD even if I break them all every time).

Hope this comes in handy for someone else!

description.text:
This is inspired by the "One of Us" scene in Freaks. This was modeled in OpenSCAD using a blend of two of these goblet designs from Vecteezy (https://www.vecteezy.com/vector-art/84492-medieval-goblet-vector-set). To make it a bit more interesting I rotate_extruded the base using fewer faces while leaving the bowl/cup part smooth.

It's modeled as a solid shape. To make a goblet, print with 0% infill and no bottom layers.

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

0-5%

Notes:

For best results, I had to split this model and print it in two parts. I split it at the point where the stem meets the bowl (106mm from the top).

The bowl of the cup was printed with the widest part oriented toward the build plate. I used 4 perimeters, zero bottom layers, and 3 top layers.

The stem was printed with the base oriented towards the build plate. 3 layers on top and bottom, 3 perimeters, supports turned on, and 5% infill.

For my needs, this didn't need to hold water so I used CA glue to attach the stem to the bowl before painting.

description.text:
This is a small wrench I designed to remove the wheel nuts from my Carisma GT24 R/C vehicle. The plastic wheel nuts on my car are 4.5mm in diameter and the small wrench supplied with the car was not long enough to get the nuts out of the wheels. I could not find a 4.5mm deep socket to use, so I designed this to use instead.

Some people have said the wheel nuts are 4mm but calipers showed mine at 4.5mm

Please note that I printed this standing straight up with the cross section at the bottom instead of the top, I don't know how to change orientation in Fusion 360 in relation to the 3d printing software.

Hopefully this can help someone.

If you need to model something for a lightbulb to screw into, look no further!

For some reason I needed to be able to screw a lightbulb into a barrel (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857863). No wires or power, just a bulb. I couldn't find a good way to do it, so I created this blank to use as a negative.

Take any solid object, like a barrel, place this where you want your bulb to go, and do a 'boolean difference' in meshmixer. Voila, the perfect fit for your bulb to screw into. It should fit most common bulbs, but it's designed for the most common, an A19 (first photo).

Here's a handy reference to bulb sizes, because if you're anything like me, you had no idea what an A19 was.
https://www.bulbs.com/images/resource_section/bulb-shapes-and-sizes.png

If your printer is better than my cheap one, you may want to scale the model down a tiny bit. This negative has a 62 mm bulb, where an A19 only technically needs 60mm.
I edited out the grooves in the ears. It prints so much nicer without them.

title: Lulzbot Mini Extruder v2.1 dual fan modification

description.text:
Lulzbot Mini printer doesn't have the space to support a dual fan configuration similar to that of TAZ. I came up with a solution of easily attachable second fan. When the print job is suitably small I can attach the secondary fan. The print job has to be small enough in order to run till the end without issues. Note that the fan should always be attached after the bed auto leveling process. The removable fan has an end stop trigger that prevents the fan from colliding during the end of each print session.

Be careful: If the print job is too large and the fan is attached it can brake something!

Secondary fan is fixed with 5 cylinder magnets size 6 x 3 mm. Extruder mount has a wiring harness to snake the power cables to the secondary fan mounting point. The fan is powered through two magnets.

Model has 2 versions. I recommend the 65 deg version:

  • 68 deg: Lulzbot extruder v2.1 has different tilt angle for the fan than originally. Maybe the manufacturer finds the single fan is more effective when tilted more towards the hot end. I tried this setup in dual fan configuration (orange printed parts). It cools the hot end considerably with high fan speeds. I found it difficult to maintain even 240 C temperature when both fans are blowing.
  • 65 deg: I modified the v2.1 extruder mount to have the same angle as originally (green printed parts). This eliminates excessive cooling of the hot end and in my opinion is a better compromise than the 68 deg version.

When soldering the wires to magnets I found it necessary to protect the magnet against loosing the magnetism during heating. To do so one needs a bigger strong magnet underneath the soldered magnet during the process. I used spherical magnet to avoid head conduction from soldered magnet. Then I used a bigger cylinder one underneath the sphere to further protect the magnetic field.

EXTRA: I also created a modification of the heatsink fanduct. I found that the fans I have are unnecessarily powerful in cooling the heatsink. I guided half of the air flow to the stepper motor. This makes me less worried about the stepper motor lifetime when I use the printer inside a heated chamber.

This is my brother's version of chess. He created this using the program blender.

This version is played on a 10 x 8 chess board. It contains the following pieces; King, Queen, Bishop, Archbishop, Chancellor, Knight, Rook, and Pawn. The Archbishop has the ability to move and attack like both the Knight and the Bishop. The Chancellor has the ability to move and attack like both the Knight and the Rook.

For a full description about this version of chess check out this link: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capablanca_chess

I hope you enjoy. If you print any pieces make sure to post them in the made section and comment your feedback as I am open to any suggestions.

Big fan of azurial's Belt Gizmo model, but it was too thin and prone to breaking.

I totally redrew it in Sketchup (file provided!) and made the baseplate thicker, 3mm up from 1mm. It's a lot stronger now. The included STL is a touch wider where azurial's Nixie shelf would go, so that you glue the shelf onto the surface of the board, which is much stronger than trying to saddle the shelf to the board and glue.

I then went and separated the Nixie shelf from Chrischkula's Belt_Gizmofinished-_Demo.stl in Netfabb so that it could be printed as a separate item, without having to assemble it. This file goes with the named Remodeled Gizmo board, as it was sized for a glue-down fit. The .skp matches this STL.

The Chrischkula Nixie shelf is best printed as imported, with supports turned on.

The Gizmo itself is best printed at 200 micron layers, solid for strength.

remixed_from.author: kcmj
remixed_from.title: 100mm Air raid Siren VERY  VERY  LOUD

title: 100mm Air Raid Siren
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
kcmj made a great siren. Tolerances were good. The parts fit together well. My dogs and cats became friends after I printed it. Life was good...

...until I went to the parts bin...

DUN DUN DUUUUN!!! I didn't have a motor that fit!

What's a guy with Fusion 360, some calipers, a 3D printer, and an angry wife to do?

REVERSE ENGINEER IT!!!

I don't have any specs for the motors in my drawer, so I'm including the source file so it can be modified.

Pics of the real thing and a video demonstration demonstrating the demonstrable awesomeness to follow.

3-3-18: Motor Mount V2 posted. I normally try to design things that will print without support, but I wanted to make assembly a little less fiddly, so I added a stop to the motor mount. I also renamed the files.

3-10-18: In testing the fan kept unscrewing itself at high RPM to hilarious effect. Nothing quite so funny as seeing a 3D printed air raid siren skittering down the street at breakneck speed spewing bits of itself in every direction as it rapidly self destructs. To combat this I created a fan with a clockwise rotation. I'll post an update in a few hours after a reprint the entire thing in PETG.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You should probably use a higher infill (75%-100%) for the fan. You probably shouldn't print this out of PLA. In fact, you probably shouldn't print this at all. Attaching a motor and spinning this thing at 1000+ RPM (I chickened out at 3200rpm) is not smart. Not at all. Which is, of course, why I did it.

V2 of the motor mount needs support.

There is only 1mm to spare between the top and bottom of the fan, so getting everything aligned properly could be a little fiddly. I know it's a bit of a pain, but the closer the tolerance the noisier it should be.

Attach the motor to the mount first. Then attach the fan to the motor, and make sure everything rotates freely without rubbing. If it rubs it will heat up, deform, and explode. Not a small explosion either. It will fling plastic through walls (and eyes) if it lets go at high RPM.

Once you have those to parts rotating freely, place the cover on and all the hard work you just did should be thoroughly buggered. Now do it all again to account for the cover.

Once it's all together you can apply some thin CA glue (super glue) to the joints. Be sure to get some on your fingers, and touch your face. It adds to the fun. Nail polish remover (acetone) will remove it from your appendages. Just ask your significant other to open the bottle so you don't glue the lid to yourself. Don't ask...

I can't help too much with the motor and ESC.

That's not true.

I probably could help. I just want to go to bed because it's 2am.

Post Script

Don't test this at 1am when your 4 year old is sleeping. Not only will they be impressed, it will be nearly impossible to get them back to sleep.

This thing ended up being the equivalent of 2 shots of espresso for a toddler. He was bouncing off the walls for an hour asking me to turn it on again.

My wife was also VERY happy with me. I don't think she's ever been this impressed. She spent about 10 minutes enthusiastically complementing my design and telling me how much she loves me and my creativeness.

"This project is derived from HACKberry project originated by exiii Inc.

Exiii Hackberry : une main bionique open source imprimée en 3D.
Les prothèses permettent de remplacer un membre manquant mais elles comportent plusieurs inconvénients : leur prix (entre 8.000 et 10.000 euros) mais aussi la nécessité d'entretien et la fragilité de l'appareil. Au Japon, Exiii propose une alternative, une main bionique open source imprimable en 3D. La voici en vidéo.

Dans l'optique de rendre les prothèses accessibles à tous, Exiii, une entreprise nippone a développé une main bionique open source intégralement imprimée en 3D appelée Exiii Hackberry. Son coût de fabrication n'est que de 200 dollars (179 euros au cours actuel). Au premier abord elle peut sembler assez simple mais avec ses trois servomoteurs, il est déjà possible d'ouvrir et de fermer la main voire de saisir des objets.

Le système est contrôlé par un petit capteur que l'on place sur le bras et qui s'active lors de la contraction d'un muscle. Ce prototype a pour l'instant une autonomie d'une journée et fonctionne avec un Arduino. Exiii espère qu'avec son statut open source cette prothèse sera rapidement perfectionnée et personnalisée par les utilisateurs.

Cette main assez complexe a réalisé est décrite ici sous forme d'une maquette didactique.
https://vimeo.com/223029018
Avec l'accord de la société nippone Exiii, les fichiers permettent d'imprimer les pièces du pouce et de l'index de cette maquette. Le fonctionnement de cette maquette :
https://vimeo.com/255171783
Ces maquettes sont utilisées dans le cadre des cours de technologie en collège.

print_settings.Notes:: The file Gnist2-fot and Gnist2-vice2 needs support, the others can do without.

title: EDM sinker drill for small parts

description.text: Electric discharge machine, or EDM for short is a tool to electrically remove metal from a work piece. This is specially useful to machine very hard material like tooling steel. This is a small variant using magnetic reflex (like an old fashioned ringning bell) to electrically poke a metal part and slowly erode the metal. I plan to use this to remove broken taps. It is a work in progress.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The file Gnist2-fot and Gnist2-vice2 needs support, the others can do without.

Assembly

Parts:

1x aluminum profile 30x30x260mm
1x threaded rod M4x200mm
1x threaded rod M4x60mm
4x threaded rod M4x27 mm
1x threaded rod M4x30 mm
1x threaded rod M3x115 mm
8x nut M4
8x nut M3
6x flat headed screw M4 x 8mm
1x gypsum screw to hold the profile lid
1x steel tensioner 11 x 48 x 0.5mm (packaging steel strip works fine)
1x 24V electromagnet from an electric valve
1x 24V variable power supply
2x 4x6x40mm PTFE or PE tube
1x ceramic tube 6x10x100 mm (may work with stainless steel)

The Knobs:

The M4x27mm threaded rod is forcibly screwed into the four knob2 parts. use a piece of folded paper around the threaded rod to avoid thread damage and turn it with a pair of pliers until 14 mm of the rod is left. Do the same with M4x30 into knob1 until 15mm of the rod is left, and M4x60 into knob1 with 41mm left, and last M4x200 into knob1 with 190mm left.

The foot:

Two M4x8mm goes into the back of Gnist2-fot. They are used to tension the plastic spring onto the aluminum profile to hold firmly with friction. Force the screws into the plastic hole to generate a plastic thread. Screw them until they reach the flexible tensioner in the bottom. Slide the part onto the aluminum profile and turn the screws until the plastic tensioner firmly holds the part on the aluminum profile.

The work-board:

Insert two M4x8mm into the Gnist2-bord the same way as for the foot.

The sled:

Insert a plastic expander into the top end middle hole of the aluminum profile, this is later used for the gypsum screw and profile lid.
For the Gnist2-slade the set screws need to be inserted and screwed with a smaller screw driver that can fit all the way trough the hole for the knob screw.
Insert two M4 nuts into the back of Gnist2-slade part. Insert the long M4x200mm (with the knob) into the Gnist2-lock side hole, add two M4 nuts all the way up to the plastic part. Turn the nuts together with a bit of force to lock them, but allowing the knob and rod to turn freely.
Insert the threaded rod into the back part of Gnist2-slade and turn it all the way through the two M4 nuts. Slide the whole thing onto the aluminum profile. Adjust the set screws until the part can move along the aluminum profile with a slightly bit of friction. Fasten the lid with the gypsum screw onto the aluminum profile end and the previously inserted plastic expander.
Forcibly turn Gnist2-knob2 rod into the four holes of Gnist2-slade, until they slightly comes out the other side. Bend the steel tensioner so it bows up about 7mm from a flat surface. Insert the steel tensioner into Gnist2-slade along with the 10mm ceramic tube. Turn the knobs until the tube is placed straight in the middle of the hole and held firmly by the steel tensioner.

The vice:

insert two M4 nuts into Gnist2-vilce1 part top. Screw the M4x60mm threaded rod with the knob all the way trough the two nuts and let it stick out 20mm. Add a single M4 nut to the end of the threaded rod and apply a tiny drop of superglue between the nut and threaded rod to lock it. Slide the Gnist-vice2 part onto the end nut. Insert the two 6x40mm plastic tube on each side between the vice1 and vice2 parts as a linear bearing that holds it together. Add a M4 nut in the bottom cut. Screw the M4x30 threaded rod with knob through the work-board and into this nut to hold the vice in place on the work-board.

That's it for now, more will follow.

description.text: Zauberwürfel

Remix of Smart phone stand by engphysguy

I printed off one of the original smart phone stands and was disappointed to find that the stand fell backwards when placing the phone upright or when putting a tablet in it.

I decided to add a modification to the stand--a sloped base extension--that lengthens the base and keeps the center of gravity on tall, tiled devices from ending up behind the stand, causing them to fall backwards. I chose the design modification to have a functional role but one that stays true to the original model and maintains its ease and simplicity.

I have since printed 2 and they were perfectly for larger phones and tablets.

Thank you and enjoy!

description.text:
There are lots of camera mount designs, but none of them are designed to be mounted on Z-Axis.

This Raspberry Pi Camera Mount Support is designed to be mounted on an standard RepRap printer (Prusa, Anet) in the left side of X-Axis carriage, using Motors holes to fix.

The good thing is you can have a very good angle for the camera, directly to the Extruder, and when you print big things the camera will move with the Z axis with the extruder.

Note: FreeCAD Sources Provided (feel free to change and improve).

WorkInProgress:

  1. Make an alternative case version without the Wide Angle. Fit directly the Pi Camera.

Thanks!

Requeriments Build

All you need is shown in the picture, and you can buy everything in eBay or Alliexpress. Here is the list:

  • M2x4 Screws to fix the cam to the case.
  • 2in1 0.67X Wide Angle + Micro Lens Photo Kit For Smartphone iPhone Cell Phone (Magnification: Wide 0.67X + Super Macro Lens Construction: 2 elements in 2 groups
    Dimensions(main body): 20mm (diameter) x 11.2mm (length) Dimensions (magnetic ring): 13mm (outer), 9.5mm (inner))
  • M3x30 to fix the support to the Left Servo Motor in Axis-X.
  • Flex Cable Set for Raspberry Pi Camera - White (30cm,50cm)

The wall clock in the shape of pixel heart. I glued the yellow paper behind to improve contrast. I use this lock mechanism: https://www.pearl.de/a-PE9416-3040.shtml

8 mm hole in diameter.

I liked the existing designs on thingiverse (701668 and 1863504), because of the rounded shape and the resemblance to the original part. Unfortunately they did not fit my specific Calmato. title: Housing for Smoothieboard v1.1 (versions for x3, x4 and x5)

description.text: A simple housing for Smoothieboards, versions x3, x4 and x5. With a hole for a 50mm fan to cool the stepper drivers. Cover is screwed to the printer and then the housing is screwed to the cover.

Printer:

Heavily modded Craftbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Rotate the flats downward. Use supports, but otherwise it is not a hard print. Use any plastic you like, I made it using PLA.

Clean up the print, screw on a 50 mm fan (to cool the stepper drivers), put the Smoothieboard on the spikes (I did not need any additional fixings), connect everything, screw the cover on the extrusion profile of your printer, screw the housing on the cover using 4x 3mm self-tapping screws.

I downloaded the Eagle files for the Smoothieboard PCB and used the Eagle to Fusion integration to create a component in the shape of PCB. To approximate the connector sizes, I added some simple extrusions, these are the grey blocks. I then designed around that.

description.text: I have created these arms and tensioners for the Turnigy 9XR Pro based on the original parts to refit the throttle gimbal to be able to use it with cars or boats that need a centering. The normal versions try to reproduce the original accurately, the mod versions are the ones I actually used, because they are a bit easier to print and a bit more sturdy. All files needed to reproduce / modify this are included.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.05 to 0.01

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printing the tensioner was a bit of a hassle. Even with ABS, in the end I used cooling, otherwise the part always ended up to be deformed. As a basis, try 90 degrees heatbed temperatur, 0.1 or 0.05mm layer height, 50% cooling fan and a minimum time per layer of 10 seconds to give the layers a chance to harden a bit before the next layer is added. Print speed between 25 and 50mm/s should be fine.

If you can figure out better settings, leave a comment!

I have combined 2D drawings with the 3D part in OpenSCAD. This makes it easy to customize the shape of the parts, but you have to check twice to find out what to modify in which of the files. Have fun!

A small printable version of Invaders Zim's best "friend": Gir

Made in pieces and require glue as the "one solid print" version fail in the thinnest parts.

Created from an image made with MS Paint and developed with Windows 10, 3D Builder.
Built in ABS with No Raft, 15% Infill.

title: E3D V6, 40mm Fan, Double Fan Duct

description.text:
This is a 5015 Fanduct + 40mm Hot End Cooling Fan combo for the E3D V6 Hotend.

It fits the stock X-axis from the Tevo Tarantula. Its very strong and compact. It can travel the whole x-axis. The nozzles ducts are changeable. They are held by friction. Just snap them on and off.

Just print everything.I recommend PLA, because of the tight fit of 40mm Fan Adapter.

I think it is easy to assemble.

(There is also a fully assembled STL, where you can check the the position of the parts. It might help someone. Of course you dont have to print it ;)
or take a look at this link: https://sketchfab.com/models/b2da9d6e0f9f444caf0d98f2a01274e3)

You have to scale the STL by 1000%. Little bug in my CAD-Software....

The 40mm Fan Adapter is from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354723 by loco

You need:

  • 2x 5015 Radial Fan
  • 1x 40mm Fan
  • 4x M3 x20
  • 4x M3 x12
  • 4X M4 x20

I added the Inventor Files if someone want to change something.

title: LM8LUU Bearing Block with M3 Nut trap

description.text:
This is a remix of one that I printed which had M4 Nut Traps, and was designed for an M4 Screw. This messed me up because well.... most screws on a 3D printer are M3 Sized - whoops!

So I remade the well and the screw holes on this. Print 3 or 4 and put on the underside of your carriage with the 45mm LM8LUU linear bearings.

This is going on a Wanhao V2.1 but can work on anything. It's less weight than the full enclosure ones too (less than half the weight).

title: Chisel / Plane Honing / Sharpening Jig with MR106 bearings

description.text:
The original is a nice design but the roller core didn't have bearings, or even holes all the way through!

I hacked the original part in OpenSCAD to take MR106 bearings, that are an easy push fit. The bracket could also do with its bolt holes rotating so they aren't flat on top so that it prints better, but I haven't done that yet.

Print two of these roller cores and then all the other parts from the original.

You then assemble with two M6x70 bolts and nylocs for the two pivots, and M5x20 with nuts and washers for the clamp.

title: Anet A8 E3D Extruder Carriage and X Axis Leadscrew Conversion

description.text:
Just a teaser, no print files at the moment but once finished and tested there will be, follow for progress...

This is an X Axis Leadscrew and E3D V6 conversion for the popular Anet A8 3D Printer...

The plan is to run a bearing supported leadscrew with the X axis motor end mounted on the Left.

The main carriage is much smaller and should be lighter than the original, the plan is 2 print it in 3 parts, 2 of which will be sandwiched together to make the front and back profiles and then the cap to hold the extruder, the left and right carriages will be printed as single pieces there is only 15mm added to the width of the left carriage including the stepper motor.

Things to do:
Left carriage holes.
Right carriage dimension check.
Order hardware (Bearings, longer M3 screws, M3 nuts) already have an E3D, anti-backlash nuts, 8mm leadscrew, 8mm linear bearings)
Design fan ducting.
Add mounting options for a bed levelling sensor.
Add mount position for X Axis End Stop Switch.

Please leave any comments/suggestions below...

Watch these and other items being printed live on my new YouTube channel: Please Like & Subscribe... http://bit.ly/2FNOORr

Check out my new Facebook Page: http://fb.me/3DPrintChannel

If you insert cigarettes upside down, tobacco will drop out and evacuate the cigarette. Also dispenser will fill up from droped tobacco. :-)
You should mount this dispenser with velcro strips or sticked magnets to the bike. There's enough cheap solution for "privat using" including a lighter.
Have a nice day! :-)

title: Noise cancelling flexible stand for 3D Printer

description.text:
Vibration insulating stand for 3d printers (or other noisy and vibrating things). You need one thing for each foot of the printer. Various dimensions and spring properties are customizable parameters in the OpenSCAD file. Before using it I recommend to print a sample to check the spring properties for your needs (the weight of the load).

One of the photos above shows two stands: the left one stands free, the right one carries one foot of the printer. You can see that the spring is pressed, but it does not block.

Be aware that these stands have a flat bottom surface, so they don't have much grip on the table. Before I placed my printer on the stands I sticked four small silicon bumpers in the corners underneath each stand.

On my Anycubic i3 Mega, it turned out that printing springs with twice the resolution, i.e. 2 x 0.4mm = 0.8mm) yields the best results. Springs with more material were hard to print at all on my printer, because Cura 15.04.6 produced no reliable results. So instead of changing th spring thickness you may rather want to change the spring depth / width and the number of turns.

The idea to design this thing was inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91720 (Vibration Damper v3) and others.

03-09-2018: The springs relaxed over time, so I increased the width from 10mm to 15mm, small bugfixes

description.text:
This is the 6-pounder field gun of 1841 as it was used in the american civil war.
I tried to model as accurate as possible but some parts had to be slightly changed to make them printable.
I scaled it to about 1:12 so you can use the same wheels as for the "Cannon from Castle of Buedingen" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2546674

If you prefere to print the wheels in one piece you can take the Remix that was uploaded by "Intrudermax": https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2812424

The drawing below was used as a template:

.
More historical information:
https://www.militaryfactory.com/armor/detail.asp?armor_id=660

Additional you need:

  • 3 mm x 190mm shaft from brass for the axle. You can flatten the ends with a hammer. Then drill a 1,5 mm hole.
  • Some nails and needles to fasten the fittings.
  • 3 threaded rods M3 x 40mm to fasten the cheeks
  • 1 threaded rod M3 x 18mm for the elevator
  • 1 threaded rod M3 x 22mm to fasten the stock
  • 4 theaded rods M2 x 10mm with nuts and washers for underneath cheeks
    In case you take metal hexagonal nuts better blacken them by heating and, if possible, file the M3 rectangular.

The two eye plates should be bowed about 45° to outside.
You can do it by warming them in hot water.

description.text:
This is a general purpose case for Arduino Uno or similar form factor with a hole on top for a button, rotary control and space for a 1602A LCD Display. The display and base should click in to place. I use hot-glue to secure my components (I'm lazy!) when prototyping or testing component layouts, so I left screw mounts out of this model so I can add them as required to a project's final build once things are laid out and tested!

Please feel free to remix this and add improvements! Thanks for looking and I hope it proves useful!

I recommend printing the housing upside down (With the button hole at the bottom), This makes support Generation more efficient and prints without issues on my printer.

Change log:

V3 Moves the rotary encoder back a bit to increase distance from the LCD (V1 was quite close) and relocate Arduino USB Port to the side a bit more.

author: Andraxis

description.text: Wood traain junction type "T", BRIO compatible

I want to share this litte thing with you, because it's really simple to print and it turned out to be very practical in many situations.

My main use case is tightening ropes in a transporter during a move, but you can also use it for connecting two or more ropes without knots.

I designed this support with huge amount of adjustment and few complex pieces.
You will need 3X SCS8UU (LM8UU+aluminium bearing block),ordinary in prusa clone kits and 4X M3x25 bolts
there is no belt tensioner,i suggest this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1683070 from freemark.

installation advice:
1:lower the bed as much as possible.
2:screw the chassis and belt fixation.
3:install the two extruder but do not tighten the screws.
4:lower the two hotend in the contact of the bed.
5:tighten the screws very hard on the side of the dovetail.
6:tighten the screws moderately in front of you.

My printer will spend most of it's time at home, in which case it will be running from a remote spool holder to keep my desk tidy and allow easy filament changes. Occasionally I'll be taking the printer to events or other peoples houses where I'd want to revert to a rear mounted spool holder just to keep things clean and easy.

This filament guide allows quick and easy switching between rear mounted and remote filament spool.

It requires a very small amount of light filing/sanding to get a perfect fit (nothing more than rounding off the edges etc)

Point to some rooms at your home , or
maybe point to some funny places , or
point at office rooms from the main entrance,
or from the secretary table...

Maybe point at places around you, or

Just IMAGINE what you whant to write there and make it !

You can rotate that signs at any direction and leave them on any height you wish !

CTC

Resolution:

0.2

35

Notes:

You can print the signs with or without supports or raft.
Four upper and two bottom solid layers.
Use two shells (on 0.4 nozzle).
Print with cooling.

To be able to find directions relatively your position i made N S W E letters on the bottom mount, also each one of 24 arrows is 20 deg.
At that way ,you can check at google maps the azimut of some places and put them with great accuarcy on signs from your specific location.

To make it printable from left outs, the sign itself is made of 1.5 meter of filament , so you can use all your left outs from previous prints to print that design !

To make it point at any direction , i made clips mount design ,so you can rotate the sign at any direction and leave it on any height ,as you wish !

title: Anet A8 Inductive sensor with glass

description.text:
I'm sharing this with you, because it's working perfectly in my printer.
I started to use a capacitive sensor because my glass is 0.4mm and the inductor didn't work, and the capacitive get many erros because doesn't work ok with temperature.
So I remenber that I read somewhere that inducor sensor work ok with iron and baddly with alloy.
I bought a sheet of iron 22cm x 22cm x 0.8mm and put between the alloy heated bed and the glass, and perfect now the inductive sensor works like a sharm no more big reading errors and with a glass surface.
Probably takes a bit longer to heat the bed but I don't notice anything.
I wanted to share this with you because it's a big improvement.

description.text: Es un proyecto de tecnología de 4ºESO
This is a object I made for a project. It's a replica of a Inti Mask.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

0.25

Infill:

80#
After print it I sanded it and painted it.
I modeled the piece with the program 3D max
customized with 3D Slash!

English church bell as rung in full circle ringing. This model is just under 300mm tall. The frame is only representative as these bells are commonly is sets from 3 bells to 12 bells - or even more. This should be pretty representative of most church bells in England, but they vary as widely as the imagination of those who cast and installed them. Ringing church bells is a very English pursuit not widely understood outside the British Isles and a few scattered ex-colonies. I have attached new files for the bell and headstock as the crown was too light and prone to breaking if swung vigorously. As the height of the crown changes the balance of the bell an appropriate new headstock has been included. These files are BellNew.stl and Newheadstock.stl I recently discovered that the Sterling Applications company and their distributors in the UK have been printing my design for sale without attributing the design to me. If you are interested in this bell but do not have access to a 3D printer, I encourage you to visit their website at http://www.sterling-applications.com/products/church-bell-with-frame-section
Please note that the bell shown there is my design.

I have laid out the parts on a total of nine plates, each no more than 180mm by 180mm. If made in PLA then the parts can be glued with Bostik Extrufix, a very mobile solvent weld type glue. Use very sparingly, a couple of practice/test cheeks are supplied on Plate6A. Extrufix will also dramatically strengthen PLA and should be used sparingly on the crown of the bell and the shaft of the clapper. Use short lenghts of 1.75mm and 3mm PLA for dowels.  
Assemble the bell to the crosshead with 3 cable ties and attach the clapper to the bell with a cable tie - the hole in the bell attachement point will probably need clearing with a hot bent pin as support material will have blocked it.  
Use 3mm screws and nuts to attach the stay to the crosshead, the slider to the middle cross member and the bearing caps to the body. Bearings are 608.  
A hole will need to be made in one of the segments for the rope - look on Google for pictures of church bells to determing where to make the hole and how to tie off.

description.text:
Simple, customizable pipe flange design. The design is very flexible with many parameters to change.

I intentionally left out logic to prevent values that don't make sense. For example, you can set hole amount to 1000 and the center will be disconnected from the edges. There are cases when you want to use somewhat insane values and sometimes it would be useful to have limits but for not it's up to the user.

If you have any suggestions for improvement or just want to give feedback, feel free to leave a comment.

Edit 2018-03-05: Added 2 example images and related model. Switched to using diameters as that is what you get when you measure pipes.

Edit 2018-03-06 Added offset to adjust the screw position relative to middle position and added option for counter sunk screw holes.
Removed the need to physically put in the shelves.

title: ANYCUBIC Delta/Kossel Mini/Plus Towers Reinforcement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This my NEW design of the reinforcement for the ANYCUBIC Delta/Kossel Mini&PLUS 3D Printer but works with all printers equipped with Bosch 20x20 aluminium profiles.

The structure is simple and strong and makes your printer stable.

The main parts areonly tree for each corner(more screws,nuts and washer obviously):
1) Tower support
2) Bands
3) Circular thickness

Each group must be replicated for each tower. I suggest you to apply the same parts also in the UPPER side. After this improvement the printe will be stable also with high speed prints and also if you move the printer in another place.

The real secret is to mount the printer with the tree tower perfectly orthogonal to the bases (top and bottom). If you mount the printer correctly with this reinforcement the printer will be stable in the time.

NOTE: I've included also the design of the bands (with ANYCUBIC or DELTA logo) but if you prefer you can use the simple aluminium bands with at least 2mm tickness.

To mount this structure you need for each corner:

On the tower:
1) Two hexagonal head screws M4
2) Two self-locking nuts M4
3) Two washers for M4 screws
4) Two M4 screws 15mm long
5) Two square M4 nuts

On the horizontal base:
6) Two M4 screws 15mm long
7) Two washers for M4 screws
8) Two square M4 nuts

Procedure:
a) First of all loosen the screws that locks the towers to the corners (without remove them)
b) mount the upper part of the reinforcement on the tower
c) mount the bands between the tower reinforcement and the base
d) verify the perfect othogonality between the towers and the base
e) lock all the screws of the structure (except the screws of the corners that keep the tower)
f) lock the screws of the corners that keep the tower

See the photo for detals.

The circular part named "Spessore_Tirante_Basso_V2" must be inserted between the diagonal bands and the horizontal bosch base of the pinter.

Happy prints.
Enry

Printer:

ANYCUBIC i3 Mega

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Use supports only for the reinforcement that must be attached to the tower. For the band and the thikness it is not required.
