title: UV Sensor for Wanhao D7 mask creation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I initialy created the Idea of mask generation based on a photo. Worked very well.

I was curious about how exact it works and I ordered an Adafruit VEML6070 sensor which has still rasonable sensitivity in our UV spectrum and Adafruit deliveres a programming library for easiest setup an scetch.

I shared all you need - except the Mask Generator program itselve. I used the Mask Generaor from here:
https://www.patreon.com/GarageScience
many thanks to that guy to share this.
There is an unresolved bug - I already reported ... the 2560x1440 resolution cant be used (at least from me for any reason) you can use 2/3 pixels in x and y and scale the mask to 2560x1440 pixel afterwards easily.

I designed also some housing which may be printed easily (I used FDM printing here)
all you need to know for wiring is written in the scetch...

and for electronic/Arduino Dummies.... I added a wiring picture :)

used Hardware:

  • Arduino Nano V3 clone without soldered pins (eBay 1 Euro)
  • 0.96 inch White I2C IIC Serial 128X64 OLED, Driver IC: SSD1306 (eBay 3 Euro)
  • Adafruit VEML6070 Sensor (9 Euro)

Important to know - it deliveres an value from 0 to 100 without a unit !
This is not any UV - value
It deliveres the intenity gradient over the screen which is basically that what counts.

when used to generate a Mask you my play with the brightness of the image to avoid to be too dark.

To see how it finally worked ...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o3MpzQY05OQ&feature=youtu.be

for me it makes no sence to go down to the lowest level as measured in the outer corners... preventing to reduce the curing times of "normal" sized objects

have fun

This is an ouroboros pendant.

It is inspired by Rei's supercool snake pendant from the science fiction series "Altered Carbon"!

For the real jewelry feel you may buy it in precious Sterling Silver here

Please enjoy :)


What does Wikipedia have to say about ouroboros?
The ouroboros or uroborus (/ˌjʊərəˈbɒrəs/; from Greek οὐροβόρος from οὐρά, "tail," and -βορος, "devouring") is an ancient symbol depicting a serpent or dragon eating its own tail. Originating in ancient Egyptian iconography, the ouroboros entered western tradition via Greek magical tradition and was adopted as a symbol in Gnosticism and Hermeticism, and most notably in alchemy. Via medieval alchemical tradition, the symbol entered Renaissance magic and modern symbolism, often taken to symbolize introspection, the eternal return or cyclicality, especially in the sense of something constantly re-creating itself. It also represents the infinite cycle of nature's endless creation and destruction, life and death.

title: Keyboard Hand Grenade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this for when you absolutely need to yell on the internet. I've seen many renderings of this online before, but this might be the first actual keyboard hand grenade that works! It has 27 keys (26 roman letters and space) and therefore you may only write in CAPS (as is appropriate). However, I've added a double-tap function, so you can give every key a second function.

Inside is a Teensy-LC in keyboard mode, so it will be recognised by any computer as normal keyboard. I did not use a keyboard matrix, but used a separate I/O pin per key (therefore only 27 keys) due to space issues. The firmware is included to be programmed on the Teensy with Teensyduino.

The keys are made using OpenSCAD from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:468651

Detonator head and handle are from the combustible Lemon: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10718

author: Garibeos

description.text:
Calibration tower
10;10;30mm

This is a re-work of Automata - Marble Machine by Sebastian Bolona, to make it more suitable for 3d printing.

It has the following parts:

  • base
  • top
  • shaft
  • nut (goes on the end of the shaft)
  • cams (five of these needed - fit alternatively up and down on the shaft)
  • lifts (five different ones, of increasing height)

The finished machine works best with 6.35mm ball bearings.

The parts are designed with 0.2mm clearances, but you may need to file them a bit depending on the accuracy of your printer. The design was done in Fusion 360, and the design file (as a .step) is included in case you want to adjust anything.

The cams have a hexagonal hole to thread onto the hexagonal section of the shaft, so nothing needs to be glued.

How to support me?

Step 1 - Mount support frame
  • Put the support frame between the two PCBs. You don't wanna destroy the SMD parts under the screen PCB. Orient the support frame as shown in the pictures
  • Begin with the bottom left hole and use a screw to fix the frame
  • Rotate the frame around the Display until all holes are in aligned and in sync between support frame and display. You need to bend the frame a little bit.
Step 2 - Prepare the bottom shell

Take a screwdriver and remove the support of the holes. Apply all four screws as shown in the pictures.

Step 3 - Prepare the top shell

Put the reset knob in the the middle hole of the top case and put the display into the top shell.

Step 4 - Connect the top and bottom shell

Put the bottom shell into the top shell and fasten the screws. The holes in the top shell are already threaded!

Website

https://mightynozzle.com

description.text: This is a base to hold rods attached to optics equipment for optical experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

Use the OpenSCAD files to customize it for your application, print on your favorite open source 3-D printer and enjoy. The optics base here comes in two flavors. In the first it is just flat to be used on a normal table. In the second it has a small cylinder cut out in the bottom meant to glue in a magnet - then quasi-permanently hold the position of the component on a magnetic surface. If you wish to remove or add the hole for the Magnet in the .Scad file, change the line: magnet_hole = true; to: magnet_hole = false; Full information here: http://www.appropedia.org/Open-source_optics_base Thanks to Xin and Nick for designs. This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

remixed_from.title: Servo driven tracked rover w/suspensions (self tightning belts).

description.text:
Unlike the original, this requires only 8 bearings 627z or 608 (like spinner), making it more economical but preserving the resistance of the wheels.
In addition, I created a support for the raspberry pi 3 and another to hold an Lm2596 module to reduce the voltage of a 4S battery that had fallen into disuse.

The base.stl or Main, is based on the design of diass07.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1736808/#comment-1202412

I did not edit the ServoGear, Left_skirt, right_skirt and track_175mm files, but I upload the original lynlim design for ease of the user who wants to download the project.

3D - Parts

  • x1 - base
  • x1 - Back Right2
  • x1 - Back Left2
  • x1 - RaspBerry_Support
  • x1 - RaspBerry_Support_2
  • x1 - RaspBerryMount
  • x3 - suspension damper Pin1
  • x3 - suspension damper Pin2
  • x8 - TapaRueda
  • x2 - trackwheelBack
  • x2 - trackwheelTop
  • x4 - Trackwheelunder
  • x1 - Front
  • x2 - ServoGear
  • x1 - Left_skirt
  • x1 - right_skirt
  • x66 - track_175mm

No 3D - Parts

  • x2 - Servo Motors MG996 Hacked for continuous rotation.
  • x6 - ballpen springs (the stiffer type)
  • x8 - Bearings 627z ( 7 x 22 x 7 mm), If you have 608, you need to fill...

Electronic Hardware

Whatever you want, but this design has

  • x1 - Raspberry PI 3
  • x1 - Lm2596 To reduce a 4s Battery to 5v

title: ZOHD nano talon runcam split mini mount

description.text:
A mount for runcam split mini camera for ZOHD nano talon plane.
It contains two parts - ring ant stand.

Printer:

Primacreator p120 (same as mp select mini)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

PETG/TPU

Notes:

If you print the "stand" part on it's back, supports are only needed for the pegs, and are easily removable.

The ring part i printed in tpu.
It's a tight fit, and without any other supports holds cam in place pretty well.
Also it allows you to use lense cap, and if you squeeze it just a bit, as in photos, the foam will not be visible in the picture.

The stand part i recommend printing on back side - then you'll need less supporting material. I used petg for printing, it looks very tough. Should protect electronics if the battery will slip to front. I hope the holes will be enough to allow sufficient air flow.
You'll also need 4 m2x5mm bolts, m2x6 should be ok also.
The SD card is accessible from the side, usb port is tricky to access with the usual cables, use a 90 degree micro usb plug, or make a hole in foam for easy access.
Can be glued in place for additional protection.

In Marlin, just enable the
NOZZLE_CLEAN_FEATURE

And set the positions according to your own endstop positions
Mines are
NOZZLE_CLEAN_START_POINT { 195, -15, (Z_MIN_POS + 15)}
NOZZLE_CLEAN_END_POINT { 210, 0, (Z_MIN_POS + 15)}

Then in your slicer, use
G12 P2 R6.5 S5 (for example)

in your GCODE starting sequence

title: Under Cabinet LED Power Adapter Mount

description.text:
My under-cabinet lighting needed a power-brick, so this is a mount to hold it out of sight under the cabinet. It prints in 4 parts: 2 brackets you screw into the cabinet (left/right) and two U-shaped brackets (front-back). The version I uploaded also has a protrusion on one side for holding extra wires - you can turn that off in the customizer.

This is designed with a full length of 140mm, a main-body width of 80cm, and supports 50cm long.That means the power brick is well supported, but the front/back pieces won't be touching. This size fits a fairly large power brick, doesn't use too much plastic, and just fits on the 12x12 print bed of an MPSM. The screw holes are sized for #5 wood screws.

All parts print without support, but you may need to re-orient them.

I've built the version of this part without the wire brackets and it works well. The version with brackets is printing now...

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

description.text:
This Ultimate iPhone X dock provides an all-in-one charging dock for iPhone X with a thin protective case, an Apple Watch and also Apple Airpods.
It comes in 3 possible flavors : Ultimate version : iPhone X + Apple Watch + Apple Airpods, but also lighter versions : iPhone X + Apple Watch dock only or iPhone X dock only.

Printer Brand:

BCN3D

Printer:

BCN3D SIGMA

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed using Cura 1.1.0 customised for BCN3D Sigma, using stock 'fine quality' PLA profile

This is an redesign of my previous "iPhone 6/6s and Apple Watch stand (case compatible)" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051928) to make it compatible with iPhone X and add the "airpod" charge capability.
My previous design was still compatible with iPhone X, as long as you do not use any protective case which, in my opinion, was not an option for a 1k$ phone ...
I was also lucky to get my hands on Apple Airpods and I wanted to have a all-in-one charging solution for my nightstand.
I also wanted a 'light' solution for my office desk only to charge my phone. That's why I decided to propose derived version of the ultimate dock.

You will need 1, 2 or 3 charging cables for the dock depending the option you choose. 3rd party charging cables work well as long as they have the "official" Apple charging cable shape. I personnaly bought those for my own dock and they fit well : https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B01N6PFQ8N/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1.
Note that it is "normal" that the cable must be "forced" in place so that they do not come off each time you unplug you phone or the Airpod box. Depending your printer, light sanding might be required to be able to install the cable connectors.

Like my previous design, models including the watch stand come in 2 versions : a full version that you can print if you use supports, and a 'splitted' version that can be printed without supports but will required the watch base to be printed separatly and glued (epoxy glue works fine).

Finally, before starting your print, I recommand to print the template shape, just to make sure to your iPhone X with its case will fit in the dock.

If you like my design, buy me a beer !

title: BottleStand for paint bottles ; army painter , vallejo etc

description.text:
My first ever design made in Fusion360.
Printed by my first 3d printer Prusai3 MK3.

Bottlestand for paint bottles of 2,5cm diameter.
Standard size for army painter/vallejo bottles etc.
Designed for 54 bottles / easy access and good overall vieuw of said bottles.

ONLY the pins need a raft of +/- 4mm.
all other files can be printed without rafts or supports.
original printed on Prusai3 MK3 standard PLA 0.20mm profile 210/50c* all in Prusa White PLA

How i sliced and printed the parts :

TRAY x 18
SIDE x1 + MIRROR SIDE x1
MID x1
PINS x16 (48pins in total file has a row of 3 pins)

Pin and Glue everything (plastic glue or super glue)

This will give you a bottlestand for 54 bottles of 2,5cm diameter.
Dimensions of assembled parts is 33cm wide x 21cm deep x 8cm high.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I recommend using between four and six shells/perimeters so that the resulting parts are sufficiently strong. Consider using infill greater than 50% for Part A (the base).

I started by creating a 2D drawing of the green Part B (the one with the five different shapes inside a large circle) and a second 2D drawing (a certain distance apart from the first drawing on the Z axis) with five circles inside a larger circle. I created a series of lofts between the two drawings and subtracted the resulting shapes from what was essentially a disc to create Part B. I then worked on Parts C (blue), D (red), and ended with Part A (purple). I had to figure out a way to lock Part A in place while still allowing Part C to rotate. A cylinder stacked over an hexagonal prism did the trick. I finished by smoothing the sharp edges.

description.text:
This is a Ramp design for RC Cars, I use it for 1/8 to 1/12 scale offroad cars. It turned out very good and cars get a good kick :)

I could have been faster and possibly cheaper using just scrap wood, but hey, I might as well use my printer ;)

Printer:

Foo Bar

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed with scrap ABS, but the Material doesnt really matter. I used more infill than usual to get better strength, seems tough enough.

Print parts A to D and the corner once normal and once mirrored. Then print two of each brackets. the top and bottom support pieces help to keep the wood in shape and may not be necessary.

You need a big print bed, its designed to fit on a 30x20cm beb, 20x20 is not big enough!

Get some wooden beams in roughly 50x24, I actually ended up with 48x24 which was just 0.50€ per 2m.

As for the surface of the ramp, I used some cheap wood sheet which was easy to bend in 4mm thickness (the slot is 4.4mm). Mine was 60cm wide and I decided that I build the entire ramp 60cm wide.

You need the following pieces:
2x 443mm
2x 268mm
2x 170mm
(I cut every piece just a few mm shorter than required to be 100% sure it will fit.)

3x Pieces which have the exact same length than the width of the material you will be using for the ramp surface (in my case 60cm).

use 35mm M4 hardware to assemble the frame. Wood screws to attach the prints to the wooden beams.
After printing, drilling the hole with a 7.5mm drill, than you can screw it on the valve.

http://www.3dwp.nl

Update March 5:

The fan duct has been modified to center the duct better around the nozzle. I found that on long prints the fan would sag slightly from radiant heat from the hot block. If you printed it in ABS this wouldn't happen, mine was printed in PLA. Version V2 should not have this problem when printed in PLA.

I couldn't find a fan duct that fit my printer perfect so I created my own. I think my Anet A8 is a clone because every duct I tried was off by at least a little from the perfect fit. It works better on my printer than the others I tried but this could be because it actually fits correctly.

remixed_from.author: stevenfayers
remixed_from.title: Creality CR-10 Z axis cable drag chain

title: CR-10 Ultimate Z-Box: The ideal drag chain +  X-axis stepper damper bracket + wire management solution

description.text:
This is my 1.0 release of my Utimate Z-box the the Crealitly CR-10. It combines my idea of the bracket for the dual X damper with stevenfayers drag chain design.

Currently printed in a 2 tone white and black design, but of course any colors can be used.

The 1.0 design has the following features:

  • Drag chain
  • Damper bracket for dual X dampers
  • Wire management system
  • Filament sensor
  • Hotend LED

I will soon add a cover without filament sensor mount but with filament guide.

Some features are optional. I do recommend this mod for people that have (very basic) knowledge of electronics. Depending of the features you are going to use, you will need to do some basic soldering. I have not tested with the wire extension kit, so i'm not sure if it will fit my design. Personally i prefer to cut the wires, and extend them with some extra AWG24 wire. Just solder it, and add some heat shrink.

What you will need to print:

  • 1 pce Z-Box_Housing_V1.0.stl
  • 1 pce Z-Box_Cover_V1.0.stl
  • 1 pce Filament_Sensor_V1.0.stl
  • 9 pcs Dragchain_A_type_V1.0.stl
  • 9 pcs Dragchain_B_type_V1.0.stl
  • 1 pce Bottom_Bracket_V1.0.stl
  • 1 pce Bottom_Bracket_cover_V1.0.stl

Besides these printed parts you will need the following materials:

  • 11 pcs M3x12 screws (shorter can work too)
  • 4 pcs M3x8 screws
  • 2 pcs M3x6 screws
  • 2 pcs NEMA17 stepper dampers (6mm thick)
  • 4 pcs M3x5 screws (often supplied with dampers)
  • 2 pcs M3x40 screws (for mounting of 2nd damper to stepper)
  • 2 pcs M5x50 (optional, the original bots are just 3-4mm short, but work)
  • 4 pcs Hammer head M5 nut.
  • 4 pcs M5x8 screws

Optional electronics for Filament sensor

  • General purpose limit switch. Available on aliexpress. Check out photos.
  • Thin wire to hook up switch.

Optional electronics for hotend LED.

  • 1 pce 5mm LED, red, 20mA
  • 1 pce resistor approx 600 ohm (anything between 500 and 1000 will do)

Optional electronics for hotend terminal

  • A total of 2x8 positions PCB screw terminal with 5,08 mm pitch
  • Prototype PCB with 2.54m pitch holes and a minimum size of 50mm x 25mm

Mounting of box:
1) Remove stepper (if you already have a single damper, forward to step 4)
2) Place damper on front of stepper using the the supplied screws
3) Use brass distance bolts to mount stepper. The other 2 distance bolts are not needed
4) remove 2 screws from the back of the stepper, and use M3x40 screws to mount damper
5) Screw back screws of V-slot wheels so the nut comes loose, or replace with M5x50.
6) Mount Z-box on stepper using the V-wheel screws + nuts, and mount damper with M3x6 to the Z-box (there are holes in the back for this purpose)

Mounting of bottom bracket:
1) use hammer heads + M5x8 bolts to mount to frame. See pictures for position
2) the hole on next to the bed, can be used to route the Z stepper cables

Drag chain assembly:
1) I highly recommend using braided sleeving around the wires in your dragchain.
2) Place all wire in the Z box in the right position. You will need to cut the hotend cable.
3) Snap the A and B type links together around the cable startring at the Z-box housing's integrated drag chain link. Alternate between A and B type to close chain. I should run very smooth. If it doesn't, you may have connected the wrong links with each other.
4) connect the last link bottom bracket.

Wire management
1) The extruder cable goes trough the square hole in front of the stepper connector
2) The X limit switch cable goes trough square hole at the near the bottom.
3) The hotend cable goed trough the round 11mm hole and should be routed under the PCB

When done, use a cable tie at the bottom of theZ-box to lock the cable in place.

Hotend connection terminal:
1) Cut PCB to a size of 50mm x 25mm (the 25mm can be a bit more or less)
2) Make 2 rows of 8 connector and solder them to the PCB back to back
3) Use solder (and wire) to connect the terminals together as shown in photo
4) Place PCB in housing. If it doesnt fit, sand it down a bit.
5) I recommend marking the connections with a sticker of marker pen.
6) Connect wires coming from drag chain to the back side of the terminal block
7) Connect wires coming from hotend to front side of the terminal block.

  • The (white) thermistor wires have no polarity
  • The (red) hotend wires do have a polarity, but switching them doesn't matter.
  • The fan wires do have polarity, and should be connected correctly.

Hotend LED
1) Cut the pins of the LED to approx 10mm
2) Solder the resistor to 1 of the pins. 600 ohm is a good value. Increase value for less light
3) Solder wires to the other pin of the LED, and the other side of the resistor. 10cm is plenty.
4) Use isolation material (like heat shrink) to cover any bare conductors
5) Connect to the back of the the screw terminal block on the hotend wire.
4) Push the LED into the hole on the front. Use glue if necessary.

  • LED's have a polarity, so if the LED doesn't work while the hotend is heating, try switching the wires on the terminal block. If that doesn't work you probably have a bad connection, or the hotend isnt heating.

Filament sensor
1) Route the wire/cable coming from the drag chain behind the terminal block
2) Route the wire/cable trough the square hole in the Z-box cover
3) Route the wire/cable trough the square hole in the filament sensor and underneath bridge
4) Solder the wires to the Normally Open pin and the common terminal.
5) use 4 pcs M4x8 scres to mount the sensor to the Z-box cover
6) Place to lengths of PTFE tubing in both sides of the sensor. Its important you put them all the way trough (8mm and 18mm) or the filament will wear out the sensor. Depending on the performance of your printer it can be hard to get them in. If so, carefully smooth out the holes with a small screwdriver or a long m3 screw. It the PTFE is to losse, use a little bit of glue.

  • The used llimit switch is the most standard type i could find on Aliepress. Check out the pictures for more info.
  • My CR-10 does not have a stock filament sensor. I will be connecting it to my Raspberry Pi running octoprint in a later stage.
  • In my case i will be using the NO pin (normally open) but i dont know if other the original sensor may be connected as NC (normally closed).
  • There may also be the need of some resistors depending on what you are using now. Copy the original design, or use that PCB by removing the switch, and solder the new limit switch to it using some wire.
  • There are kits available to add such a sensor to the original motherboard of the CR-10 (non S). I guess these could work with a little modification
  • I will not be advising you on how to implement the sensor output on your CR-10.

All parts are printed in PLA with a 0.4 nozzle @ 0.44 line width and .22 layer height.

Supports are NOT needed for most of this print. Only the chain link in the Z-box needs a little bit of spoort to print. I suggest using the experimental CURA tree supports. It worked great for me.

title: Sculptris Dummies: Gnomes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT!

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

These OBJ models were designed for use in Sculptris to give you a head-start creating gnomish characters. If you import them into Sculptris, their parts should remain separate and you can immediately begin sculpting and posing them any way you like.

If you make anything with these, let me know and post a link here in the comments section (and certainly post a remix when you have something printable). I'd love to see what you come up with!

You can find an expanding collection of compatible parts here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Anet A8 X-Axis Belt Tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I remixed this from the Enhanced Anet A8 X-Axis Belt Tensioner from 3DGenie_xyz, thinking i could do without the need for washers everyone was using on the axis wheel, this one uses a two part axis wheel so it prints with no need for support. All you need to do is pop the the carriage center into the carriage wheel.
I also didn't use a knob on mine i use a screw driver on the screw to adjust, so this will NOT work with an enclosure ,i.e. "ikea lack".
The carriage has also been beefed up by adding a more enclosure type feel to it, with the original one i keep break the thing trying to get the wheel in, this keeps it more firm for me.

Make one and let me know ...

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2593758

Yet Another Stanley Blade Holder (YASBH). :)
This is a minimalistic blade holder for the Stanley 1992 utility blades. It is intended for the normal thickness blades, which are 0.61 mm / .024 in.

Just put the blade in the base part, as far down as it will go, and then slide the wedge part in, to fix the blade in place.

The blade is not retractable.

It is not intended for heavy-duty use! The casing is plastic and quite thin. Be careful, so you don't cut yourself! I use mine as a box-cutter.

I don't make use of the two slots in the back of the blade. I simply put the blade as far down it can go, and then use the wedge-part to hold the blade in place by friction.
I found it messy to insert blades in this construction if I made use of slot-pins.
I wanted to make the holder as minimalistic as possible, thus I only went with the bare essentials.

To remove blade, I recommend pulling the blade out with a pair of pliers. Just pull straight out. Be careful not to cut yourself!

Added a simple sheath as well. The design of this is a bit "quick and dirty" as I initially didn't intend for a sheath. Will probably come an improved version later on.
The sheath should be printed standing up, and without supports (see pictures).

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.15

20%

Notes:

There is a slight overhang in the base part, to accommodate the wedge. But I skipped support material here to keep the surface as smooth as possible.
I used a pretty basic PLA (From Clas Ohlson, in Sweden). Default temps.
As the tolerances are quite tight, be mindful about shrinkage if you use other materials.
Minimal amount of sandpapering. Just to make it smooth. Fine grit.
Designed from scratch in Fusion 360. Used caliper and a Stanley 1992 blade to figure out dimensions. Also downloaded an image from Stanley and used as a template in Fusion 360.

description.text:
This is a 32mm (radius) spool for offcuts of wire to keep your electronics box tidy. They hold about 16m of 'jumper' wire.

The cover is optional but keeps the wires from springing out.
The cover needs a brim except for the stickiest of print beds due to the low surface area touching the bed.

the two sides of the spool snap together with force and are unlikely to come apart after assembly, so I would suggest threading the end of the wire on to the wire holder in the spool and through the hole in the cover before fully assembling, you can then fully assemble - if you are not using the cover then this doesn't matter.

I've included the sketch-up files if anyone wants to modify, correct, improve the design.

title: European Power socket Kitchen Mounting box

description.text:
I hate the way European power sockets constantly come away from their stupid mounting in concrete walls. I decided to design my own.

This box goes with my double faceplate to accept two standard EU power sockets. It then mounts at the back of the kitchen worktop, (with a space at the back for cable to rise) against the back wall. I am mounting a few of them on the new kitchen units.

They have: Sufficient space underneath to allow ugly transformers to fit.

Cabling gap at the rear, so your wiring can stay hidden behind the kitchen units.

Pre made, countersunk holes for the faceplate and plastic blocks behind, so the plate can be fixed in place with wood screws. (They are hidden from view by the power socket surround)

Pre drilled holes for mounting to the kitchen top, no need to make holes in your walls!

Accept standard EU power sockets. Just dismantle and mount

Remember that you need a licensed electrician to install sockets, unless you make them up as an extension lead.

The standard sockets have little flanges at the rear. These fit in slots in the faceplate to keep the sockets square. Check before you buy the sockets. I paid 3 Euros each for them.

title: IQAudio Pi DAC Zero plus Headphone Case

description.text:
This is a snap-together case for a raspberry pi Zero W and attached IQAudio Pi Zero DAC plus Headphone Amp. Top and Bottom each take about 1.5 hours to print.
Assembly:
1) mount 1x M2.5/9mm standoff on post closest to USB power input, for later attachment to PI dac
2) use 3x M2.5/3mm machine screws to mount the Pi Zero. Pi Zero must have male headers
3) mount 3x M2.5/12mm standoffs from Pi DAC to Headphone Amp
4) Carefully mount the Pi DAC female headers on the mounted pi zero male headers
5) Insert top case mid-way over bottom, slide back and push down starting at RCA Connector (red/white jacks), then make sure all sides are pressed down firmly.

This is "kind of" a remix. I followed the tutorial on Layer-by-Layer from Adafruit (https://youtu.be/YxBamwc6s7U), drawing the featured simple raspberry pi zero case from scratch in Fusion 360. Then I added modifications to allow for the Pi DAC.

Fusion 360 full design included here as *.f3d file, so you can change it.

My 80mm brushless micro drone frame, loosely based on the popular "Butterfly" design. Perhaps I'll make a second version that is somehow more interesting.

V 1.3
New Version: 4 zip ties - instead of stand-offs and screws. Been flying this/crashing it around on the pavement freestyle. Enjoying this extra crash protection. See image #4

Guess its still on the heavy side since I get about 5 minutes less flying time than the carbon fiber frame I was flying these parts on prior to this frame.

My favorite batteries so far 7.4v: See image #5

Needs:
Motors: 1103
Nylon standoffs x 8 size? Where's my caliper thingy?
2 regular-ish sized zip-ties. A few extra small zip ties? (For the crash cage around the camera. The clear part in my rendering is supposed to be zip-ties.) Some rubber bands to secure the camera/video transmitter unit to that piece.

A lot of file work/sanding when I print it in PETG with my Maker Select V2.

New in this version:
Mounting holes for 16mm X16mm FC. What I flew it with last night and some this morning. Fun but still needs some improvement. The camera in the picture actually didn't work, no wonder they sent it to me for free!!!!!!! Ooops. Have some others to swap out. Did once, but broke the antenna for that one. Ooops again! Forgot about crash protection for that was so eager to fly it!

I think its way on the heavy side for a 80mm Micro at 80 something grams. What I still want to work on.

Peace!

author: Point_of_view

print_settings.Notes:: 1mm shell wall. printed flat side down at 45 degree rotation around z axis for zig zag support removal.

description.text: Inspired by Adam Savage's sheet metal holster he made on "Tested" I designed a 3d printed one. It hangs lower, using a piece of a dollar store belt secured with a small bolt and nut and some 2 part epoxy because I break things too easily lol. Instead of getting the tolerance exactly right, I left it a little large and used some heat shrink tubing on the belt clip of the tool which keeps it secure while I'm doing cartwheels. On my version I added my name on the side in case I leave it behind somewhere. I printed it flat with a 45 degree z rotation so zip zag supports could be easily removed. I also ended up reversing the nut and bolt which lets the 'leather' swivel freely.

Marine GPS antenna / GPS receiver holder. Can be used with any device mounted using 1 inch / 14 TPI inner thread (14TPI is not a standard for 1 inch thread, however its still commonly used - make sure the thread fits your needs).
Created to be used with antenna, with cable going inside of mount. Can also be used with receivers transmitting data in NMEA format, the hole should be big enough.
Depending on the antenna/receiver head size you may need to edit the mount to move it away from mounting plate.
Suggested indoor use due to low thickness and lack of UV resistance of most of PET filaments.

Design edit

Design was created using FreeCad. However thread itself was first created using OpenSCAD script, then moved to FreeCAD in STL format.
In case you need to edit it you will have to generate threaded part separately.
